text: was a Japanese politician. He served in the House of Representatives for twelve terms. He became the 84th Prime Minister of Japan from 30 July 1998 to 5 April 2000. His political career ended when he suffered a serious stroke and slipped into a coma. His daughter, Yūko Obuchi, is a member of the House of Representatives. Obuchi died on 14 May 2000 at the age of 62 in Tokyo from complications of a stroke. ==References== ==Other websites== Category:1937 births Category:2000 deaths Category:Prime ministers of Japan Category:Politicians from Gunma Prefecture Category:Liberal Democratic Party (Japan) politicians Category:Foreign ministers of Japan Category:Chief Cabinet Secretaries of Japan
title: Keizō Obuchi
